facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 6, 1957, of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur, in Misc. Petition No. 512 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 6, 1957, of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur, in Misc. Petition No. 512 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant is the manager of a biri factory in Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the manager of a biri factory in Nagpur. Respondents 2 to 4 are working in that factory.

facts.text: Respondents 2 to 4 are working in that factory.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the manager of a biri factory in Nagpur. Respondents 2 to 4 are working in that factory.

facts.text: Respondents 2 to 4 applied for leave for fifteen days from December 18, 1955, to January 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: They applied for leave for fifteen days from December 18, 1955, to January 1, 1956, and did number go to work during that period.

facts.text: Respondents 2 to 4 did not go to work during that period.

anchor.surface_text: They applied for leave for fifteen days from December 18, 1955, to January 1, 1956, and did number go to work during that period.

facts.text: Appellant did not pay their wages for these days.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did number pay their wages for these days and in companysequence they applied to the Payment of Wages Authority

facts.text: Respondents 2 to 4 applied to the Payment of Wages Authority for payment of wages which had been withheld.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did number pay their wages for these days and in companysequence they applied to the Payment of Wages Authority  hereinafter called the Authority  for payment to them of wages which had been withheld.

facts.text: Claim was that they were entitled to fifteen days leave in the year under ss. 79 and 80 of the Factories Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Their claim was that they were entitled to fifteen days leave in the year under ss. 79 and 80 of the Factories Act, 1948.

facts.text: The Authority allowed the claim and granted them a sum of Rs. 90/16/- as wages which had been withheld for the period of leave.

anchor.surface_text: The Authority allowed the claim and granted them a sum of Rs. 90/16/- in all as wages which had been withheld for the period of leave.

facts.text: Appellant filed an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court at Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the appellant filed an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court at Nagpur.

facts.text: Appellant's main contention was that respondents 2 to 4 were not workers within the meaning of the Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: His main companytention was that respondents 2 to 4 were number workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and companyld number therefore claim the benefit of a. 79 thereof

facts.text: Respondents contended that they were workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and entitled to the sum awarded.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companytended that they were workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and were entitled to the sum awarded to them by the Authority.

facts.text: High Court concluded that respondents 2 to 4 were workers under s. 2(1) of the Factories Act and dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a companysideration of the circumstances came to the companyclusion that respondents Fir2 to 4 were workers under s. 2 1  of the Factories Act and therefore the order of the Authority was companyrect and dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Appellant applied for a certificate to appeal to this Court which was refused.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for a certificate to appeal to this Court which was refused.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from this Court.

anchor.surface_text: He then obtained special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has companye up before US.

facts.text: Respondents work at the factory and are not at liberty to work at their homes.

facts.text: If any worker comes after midday he is not supplied with tobacco and is thus not allowed to work.

anchor.surface_text: but if any worker companyes after midday he is number supplied with tobacco and is thus number allowed to work, even though the factory closes at 7 p.m.

facts.text: Factory closes at 7 p.m. in accordance with the provisions of the Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: even though the factory closes at 7 p.m. in accordance with the provisions of the Facts of the Factories Act

facts.text: Standing orders in the factory: a worker who remains absent for eight days can be removed.

anchor.surface_text: There are standing orders in the factory and according to those standing orders a worker who remains absent for eight days  presumably without leave  can be removed.

facts.text: Payment is made on piece-rates according to the amount of work done.

facts.text: Management has the right to reject biris that do not come up to the proper standard.

anchor.surface_text: The payment is made on piece-rates according to the amount of work done but the management has the right to reject such biris as do number companye up to the proper standard.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 2(1) defines a worker to mean a person employed, directly or through any agency, whether for wages or not, in any manufacturing process, or in cleaning any part of the machinery or premises used for a manufacturing process or in any other kind of work incidental to, or connected with, the manufacturing process, or the subject of the manufacturing process.

concepts.interpretation: Includes piece-rate workers under factory supervision and control.

His main contention was that respondents 2 to 4 were not workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and could not therefore claim the benefit of s. 79 thereof The respondents contended that they were workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and were entitled to the sum awarded to them by the Authority.

issues.text: whether respondents who are workers under s. 2(1) are entitled to leave under s. 79 despite ability to absent themselves whenever they like and remaining absent for longer than provided

anchor.surface_text: Then it was urged that even if the respondents are workers under s. 2(1), s. 79 should not be applied to them as they can absent themselves whenever they like. In this very case it is said that the respondents remained absent for a longer period than that provided in the Act and therefore they do not need any leave. This argument has in our opinion no force.

holdings.text: the test laid down in Dharangadhara Chemical Works with respect to s. 2(s) of the Industrial Disputes Act would also apply to s. 2(1) of the Factories Act

anchor.surface_text: In Dharangadhara Chemical Works 1 , this Court held with reference to s. 2 s  of the Industrial Disputes Act, which defined workman that the word employed used therein implied a relationship of master and servant or employer and employee and it was number enough that a person was merely working in the premises belonging to another person. A distinCtion was also drawn between a workman and an independent companytractor. The prima facie test whether the relationship of master and servant or employer and employee existed was laid down as the existence of the right in the employer number merely to direct what work was to be done but also to companytrol the manner in which it was to be done, the nature or extent of such companytrol varying in different industries and being  1  1957 S.C.R. 152.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent from Chintaman Rao which applied Dharangadhara test to Factories Act s.2(1)

holdings.text: the prima facie test whether the relationship of master and servant or employer and employee existed was laid down as the existence of the right in the employer not merely to direct what work was to be done but also to control the manner in which it was to be done

anchor.surface_text: The prima facie test whether the relationship of master and servant or employer and employee existed was laid down as the existence of the right in the employer number merely to direct what work was to be done but also to companytrol the manner in which it was to be done, the nature or extent of such companytrol varying in different industries and being by its nature incapable of being precisely defined.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming control test from precedents as applicable metric for employment under s.2(1)

holdings.text: respondents 2 to 4 who work in this factory cannot be said to be independent contractors

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we are of opinion that respondents 2 to 4 who work in this factory cannot be said to be independent company- tractors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts differ substantially from Chintaman Rao where sattedars were independent contractors with sub-contracting freedom

holdings.text: the mere fact that a worker is a piece-rate worker would not necessarily take him out of the category of a worker within the meaning of s. 2(1) of the Factories Act

anchor.surface_text: The limited freedom which respondents 2 to 4 have of companying and going away whenever they like or of absenting themselves  presumably without leave  is due to the fact that they are piece-rate workers but the mere fact that a worker is a piece-rate worker would number necessarily take him out of the category of a worker within the meaning of s. 2 1  of the Factories Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Piece-rate payment does not negate worker status if control and supervision present

holdings.text: it is the right to supervise and not so much the mode in which it is exercised which is important

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the operation being a simple one, the companytrol of the manner in which the work is done is exercised at the end of the day, when biris are ready, by the method of rejecting those which do number companye up to the proper standard. In such a case it is the right to supervise and number so much the mode in which it is exercised which is important.

holdings.reasoning_summary: For simple manufacturing like biri rolling, end-of-day rejection suffices as control over manner without constant supervision

holdings.text: there can be no doubt that respondents 2 to 4 are workers within the meaning of s. 2(1) of the Factories Act

anchor.surface_text: Considering the entire circumstances and particularly the facts that if the worker does number reach the factory before midday he is given numberwork, he is to work at the factory and cannot work else- where, he can be removed if lie is absent for eight days companytinuously and finally his attendance is numbered and biris prepared by him are liable to rejection if they do number companye up to the standard, there can be numberdoubt that respondents 2 to 4 are workers within the meaning of s. 2 1  of the Factories Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative facts (factory work only, attendance marked, no late work, removal for absence, rejection right) establish control satisfying employment test

holdings.text: This argument has in our opinion no force

anchor.surface_text: Then it was urged that even if the respondents are workers under s. 2 1 , s. 79 should number be applied to them as they can absent themselves whenever they like. In this very case it is said that the respondents remained absent for a longer period than that provided in the Act and therefore they do number need any leave. This argument has in our opinion numberforce.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects contention that irregular attendance precludes s.79 leave

holdings.text: The leave provided under s. 79 arises as a matter of right when a worker has put in a minimum number of working days and he is entitled to it. The fact that the respondents remained absent for a longer period than that provided in s. 79 has no bearing on their right to leave

anchor.surface_text: The leave provided under s. 79 arises as a matter of right when a worker has put in a minimum number of working days and he is entitled to it. The fact that the respondents remained absent for a longer period than that provided in s, 79 has numberbearing on their right to leave, for if they so remained absent for such period they lost the wages for that period which they would have otherwise earned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.79 leave earned as right after threshold days; excess absence forfeits extra wages but preserves leave right and wages for leave period

holdings.text: they were entitled under s. 79 of the Factories Act to proportionate leave during the subsequent calendar year if they had worked during the previous calendar year for 240 days or more in the factory

anchor.surface_text: That however does number mean that they should also lose the leave earned by them under s. 79. In the circumstances they were entitled under s. 79 of the Factories Act to proportionate leave during the subsequent calendar year if they had worked during the previous calendar year for 240 days or more in the factory. There is numberhing on the record to show that this was number so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence they failed minimum days; thus entitled to s.79 leave wages

anchor.surface_text: The prima facie test whether the relationship of master and servant or employer and employee existed was laid down as the existence of the right in the employer number merely to direct what work was to be done but also to companytrol the manner in which it was to be done, the nature or extent of such companytrol varying in different industries and being by its nature incapable of being precisely defined.
In the circumstances the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: The limited freedom which respondents 2 to 4 have of companying and going away whenever they like or of absenting themselves  presumably without leave  is due to the fact that they are piece-rate workers but the mere fact that a worker is a piece-rate worker would number necessarily take him out of the category of a worker within the meaning of s. 2 1  of the Factories Act.
In the circumstances the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the entire circumstances and particularly the facts that if the worker does number reach the factory before midday he is given numberwork, he is to work at the factory and cannot work else- where, he can be removed if lie is absent for eight days companytinuously and finally his attendance is numbered and biris prepared by him are liable to rejection if they do number companye up to the standard, there can be numberdoubt that respondents 2 to 4 are workers within the meaning of s. 2 1  of the Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: Then it was urged that even if the respondents are workers under s. 2 1 , s. 79 should number be applied to them as they can absent themselves whenever they like. In this very case it is said that the respondents remained absent for a longer period than that provided in the Act and therefore they do number need any leave. This argument has in our opinion numberforce.
In the circumstances the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: h8 resolves i2 by explaining that leave under s.79 is a matter of right after minimum days, unaffected by longer absences

anchor.surface_text: The leave provided under s. 79 arises as a matter of right when a worker has put in a minimum number of working days and he is entitled to it. The fact that the respondents remained absent for a longer period than that provided in s, 79 has numberbearing on their right to leave, for if they so remained absent for such period they lost the wages for that period which they would have otherwise earned.
In the circumstances the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: h9 addresses i2 by affirming entitlement to proportionate leave under s.79 based on prior working days

anchor.surface_text: That however does number mean that they should also lose the leave earned by them under s. 79. In the circumstances they were entitled under s. 79 of the Factories Act to proportionate leave during the subsequent calendar year if they had worked during the previous calendar year for 240 days or more in the factory. There is numberhing on the record to show that this was number so.
In the circumstances the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Issue directly concerns meaning of worker under s. 2(1) of Factories Act, the cluster concept.
i1 on whether respondents are workers under s. 2(1) Factories Act is addressed by independent contractor doctrine in c8
i1 on worker status is addressed by h3 holding they are not independent contractors
i1 on whether workers under s. 2(1) is addressed by h6 holding they are workers
i2 concerns whether entitlement arises under s.79 despite absences, requiring application of c4
a5 cites Dharangadhara Chemical Works (p1) and states it supports respondents not being workers
p1 (Dharangadhara) lays down the master-servant test under Industrial Disputes Act s.2(s), which c6 applies analogously to Factories Act
p1's master-servant test is applied analogously to determine worker status under Factories Act in i1
p2 applies Dharangadhara test to determine worker status under Factories Act, establishing basis for independent contractor doctrine in c8
p2 explicitly states the test from Dharangadhara applies to s. 2(l) Factories Act, directly supporting h1's holding that the test applies to s. 2(1) of the Factories Act
Precedent on similar biri workers as s. 2(1) workers supports definition.
Precedent on similar workers supports holding.
Precedent supports affirmative resolution of worker issue.
